abstract.text: Displays a standard system interface to generate images from
the provided input.

inlineContent.text: system interface to generate images from a description you provide.
People use the view controller interface to generate images and
experiment with the contents before returning an image to your app.
You can then incorporate that image into your appâ€™s content.
initial description of the image you want before you present it.
Specify a text-based description of the image using the
property. If you have a starting image that you want to use to create
the new image, specify your image in the
Present this view controller from your interface and wait for it to
approves the image, the view controller sends that image to your app
via this delegate object. The view controller also notifies your
delegate if the person cancels the operation.

abstract.text: Present a system interface to generate images based on descriptive information.
A policy for enabling or disabling personalization in the system interface.
Displays a standard system interface to generate images from
the provided input.
An interface you use to receive images and handle events related
to an image-generation view controller.
A list of allowed generation styles to choose from in the playground.
An array of elements that describes the expected contents of the image.
The delegate object that receives the generated image and
handles events from the view controller.
Creates a new image-generation view controller for you to present.
A Boolean value that indicates whether image generation
is available on the current device.
The presentation style for modal view controllers.
The policy to apply when determining whether to include people in generated images.
Generation style to pre-select upong launching the playground among those in
An image to use as source input for generating the new image.
A controller that manages a view, typically loaded from a nib file.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A set of methods that support the mediation of a custom segue.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an objectâ€™s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
